review_blob: Im generally disappointed with German craft brews (often compromise attempts at brewing other styles, or outright bad attempts), but this one works across all sorts of dimensions. A mild sour bite to start with overtones of cherry and chocolate, a fun fizzy liveliness with a sweet richness anchoring it, and mildly complex dimensions of bitter, yeasty, fruity finishing fairly long. The 9% hides itself completely, until you are finished with the thing. I think this is a really enjoyable beer - - its almost fun, which I think is an adjective I havent used yet in a beer review.

Had this on tap at a casual bar in Madison after getting a Rogue Dead Man that was flat and off. Asked for the Victory Saison as an alternate, and what a brillant storming success this beer is. Subtle hops layers but all this fruit and spice just delighting, up and down. A fresh, vibrant, taste bomb - - a full pint, and from beginning to end a joybunny. Really well conceived - - saisons can be lawnmower beers when done half-a@@ed, but this one hits top notes up and down. A really inspired, zoomy, fruity, hop-tinged, spicy pretty thing.
beer_name: Dogfish Head / Victory / Stone Saison du BUFF

review_blob: Sour bite, fizz attack, malty rich backbone sneaking up - - dances all over the palate and keeps biting the palate yo royal. No straining for flavor, or substance, with this gose - - it is like lemonade from Pluto with an incoming malt bomb from Venus, soaked in lemon rinds from Mars. Hits you up real good. No falling asleep with this one.
beer_name: Destihl Wild Sour Series: Here Gose Nothin

review_blob:
The GOOD: RIch, full flavored; lots of roasted malt; big body beer with rafts of flavor across multiple dimensions.

The BAD & THE UGLY: Unbalanced and ultimately unpleasant; roasty malts get torpedoed by the hops, which are simple and bitter; licorice predominates in the flavor arena; finish is deadly.

Do they actually taste their beers before they bottle them, or do they just use a recipe and hope for the best? The dedication to full-bodied ingredients (and high ABV) is exemplary, but the execution is awful.

Gosh I hope the other two I bought from this brewer arent the unsatisfying mish-mosh this one is. It has the bright maltiness of a lager, the sweetness of a belgian blonde, and the hops of a monochrome bitter IPA. In other words, it is an ungodly mess. Sticky on the lips, dankly bitter, cloying - - at first promising in all sorts of different directions but delivering in none of them, and a bit of a horrorshow as they combine. Another German craft beer that is a big belly-up if you are used to the competitively innovative and very high standard of U.S. craft beers.

A truly primitive rendition of an Imperial IPA. Murky, bitter hops, some off caramel notes with a touch of cloying sweetness, light fizzy mouthfeel. Unbalanced, unrewarding, and unnecessary. 

 Its beers like this that set the craft beer movement back 25 years.

And I forgot I told myself not to by their beers anymore, because the last one had a capped that leaked a puddle of fluid onto the floor of the bus. This one also started leaking spray all over the rest of the stash I bought, though not as terribly. Still, it was a mess, as is this beer.
beer_name: Hffner Bru Hopfenstopfer Seasonal Special Ale

review_blob: I used to be a tripel & quad guy and thought dubbels were a bit too Newcastle Brown until I started finding fab small label and aged joys in Belgium. I used to not be an Ale Asylum fan either, even though they are just down the road. But this is really impressive - - I like aged dubbels, but the freshness is super - - the roasty malts to start are delicately warming and sweet, and then things start to really zoom with a huge range of spice / hop / precious-metal complexity, Every sip is a gothic cathedral spire. Brilliant.

Im usually a big fan of Imperial Anything but wit is a delicate, fresh, light&bright; style with nuanced accents of fruit and spice. This Imperial Wit instead is a syrupy thing - - densely sweet, backed up with a medicinal antiseptic/alcohol spine. Seriously, it tastes like apricot cough syrup. The mouthfeel is great though. Its sort of an overcompensation from the frustration that overly light wits sometimes leave you with - - you long for just a bit more flavor, a bit more intensity, a bit more substance. This is the antidote for that, but its more an odd duck than something really enjoyable.
The mouthfeel is nice, as is the touch of sourness, and the carbonation is pleasantly zesty. Otherwise, it is a watery & slight bit of not much of anything. Seriously inconsequential.

The creamy richness of this brew is hard to match - - then comes roasty sweetness countered and enhanced by pings and pangs of pretty, but still assertive hops. To quote Matthew Arnold, its "a darkling plain swept with confused alarms of struggle and flight, where ignorant armies clash by night" but the armies are a pitched battle between frothy rich sweet warm stout and lovely strong hops - - and the brewer is definitely not ignorant. The mouthfeel alone is stratospheric. Note: I did drink this at room temperature and I can recommend the same.

For me, this is a miss. Its not lush as a beverage (its more dense and steely in texture); its not florid & open in its aromas (most flavor comes from sourness and bitterness on the tongue), and the flavors are confused and unpleasant - - tree bark, aluminum, and dusty spice rack. Its lean, metallic, and close to astringent.

Having this reminds me of having the Green Flash Imperial IPA a decade or more ago for the first time. That one so stained the palate with pine that it was like chewing on the Xmas tree when you were three. This psycHOPath goes beyond that as a winner in the distinctive department. It is almost lemony astringent on the palate, but with malts that add sweetness and fullness. Despite nice richness, the pine/citrus is pleasantly extreme. If you had told me they had it was actually made with the sap of a balsam fir, I would just nod. Thats why I like it so damn much. Its a big sharp punch in the palate, followed by rivers of oozing bite scraping down your gullet. A very fresh tonic for anyone double-IPA-jaded.

Got this bottle at Ratsherrn (Altes Maedchen) in Hamburg. Weizens tend to have banana & clove flavors; this has banana, clove, lemon, and pine. The mouthfeel is sheer joy - - full, rich, silky, frothy. The hops are an absolute sublime complement to typical weizenbier flavors - - they add a gentle sleek,piney, almost minty frame that gives this weizen a cool freshness that tempers the fruity froth. Really a fun beer, and exceptionally well integrated flavors.

This tastes like cherry plum brandy, but on a rich, woodsy, frothy frame. Its amazing how fruity it turns out, with woodiness, caramel, and sweet roasty-toastiness showing rare sides to themselves. There is a twist of bitters to keep it honest. The texture is a delight - - smooth, fine, zesty, supple carbonation. I know Im going bonkers with the adjectives here, but its deserved. Yes, there is a booziness to it. A triumphal, swaggering booziness.

In my "fruitless" quest for the ultimate tripel, got this at a Rouses in Houma, LA. I remember asking the owner at de Bierkoning in Amsterdam what tripel might be good, and he shrugged disdainfully and said, "everybody makes a triple nowadays." This has zesty lemony attack and peachy/mango/apricot fruit; it has a nice kick with its 10%. The texture is rich & frothy as blonde beers go, and although the overall balance approaches sweet, a touch of tart and bitter round it out great. This beer makes it worthwhile to keep questing, and I would happily get it again.
beer_name: Samuel Adams (Barrel Room Collection) New World Tripel

review_blob: In comparison to other citrus/pine mega-IPAs (e.g., Hopslam, Hoptimum) this one clocks in real nice with huge rich hoppiness, syrupy richness, but also dryness. It has no cloying sweet to muck it up. In fact, it is almost tart, and the different aspects wind up with all sorts of definition: fresh & zesty; spring woodland hoppy; bitingly alive. This is a stunning beer, but it is big, big, big, and bracing too.

I cant believe Im drinking the same beer others are describing, but it does say Stillwater Existent on the label. This is a bitter, unpleasant beer with no redeeming aspects. The hops are total tree bark, roots, and surrounding soil. On the other hand, the palate is light and fizzy, almost watery. Fantastically unbalanced, with the phosphate carbonated character not exactly overcoming the morbid hop skeleton. Like drinking swampwater scooped out an empty tomb - - maybe a plum did fall in there and then decomposed (and yes, as another poster mentioned, it does have the aroma of old gym socks).

A trip I took to Belgium a couple years back I brought the Black Albert, some Westy 12, and others to Hamburg and we did a couple tastings. The Westy 12 was grand, but everybody no exception was more and most flummoxed by the Black Albert. I got a few bottles today at Hop Duvel in Ghent, and I thought the Prearis Quad I had just before it was sublime, and hard to top, but the Black Albert (Batch 0) is such a no-contest slam down. I think what it does is take densest burnt smoky malts, and sends it all up like fireworks with brilliant yeasts, sugars, and finest carbonation. It is a rich, complex, heavy-body-by-nature thing, that somehow instead manages to explode, into sparklers and stars.

This is turning into one of my favorite beers - - and a particular godsend since I spend half the year in Germany (where the craft beer movement is just now STARTING to get some traction). For a weizenBOCK the Vitus is lush and lovely - - the banana and clove are wafting, enchanting. For a WEIZEN it has an assertiveness and fullness that is lacking in most weizens. Absolutely delicious. This combination of fullest weizen character with bockish assertiveness and a gorgeous frame rules supreme.

Going over the top with Lil Sumpin. Best value on the shelf, bar none. Rafts of bright strong hop flavor with complex developing palate that goes on forever, with a golden color and nice head - - this is the yellow brick road incarnate. What the delightful hops do atop the dappling yeast character is vast and wonderful. It reminds me of the superb Duvel Triple Hop, but is so integrated and natural - - a quintessential, essential brew that at this price could be a daily luxury, and with all that style and grace, it is, like, really sumpin.
beer_name: Lagunitas A Little Sumpin Wild Ale

review_blob: Its all about pleasant flavors - - plums and figs and carob.  Not much carbonation, and its kind of light on the palate.   Just kind of sits there in the glass.   But very, very tasty, with enough zest and gentle bittering to make it very well-rounded.  P.S. the bottle looks fab.

Fantastic, pillowy, lush head - - delicious on its own.   Then silky smooth sipping - - before the hops start to bite home.  Bigger and far more assertive than most anything in any pub from Newquay to Newcastle, the hops get good and stiff, but some candy-like malt keeps it friendly.  A really unique and worthwhile brew.  Its fun to drink stuff like this.

The roasty malts are there, but still its kind of simple and sweet.  Minimal head, thins out on the palate.  All the basic elements of an imperial stout are there, but it all seems kind of pooped out, with the sweetness predominating, which is not a good thing.

Mildly sweet, but well balanced with fragrant, herbaceous hops.  Fabulous head and rich mouthfeel.  Looks gorgeous too.  Lovely confluence of delicate, herby/sweet flavors, great palate, and fine touch of hops.   I dont usually drink single IPAs, but when I do, I appreciate a classy little number like this one.

Pleasantly zesty with a light fruity density on the palate;  a touch of apricot and then some light tree-bark hops.   Sour, sweet, and bitter all vie for attention, with none of them succeeding and the flavors cancel each other out to make for an overall simple beer that is not all that pleasurable, really.  If anything, the mouthfeel is the best thing about it.  Dont need to have it again terribly soon.

Very little carbonation but nice lightly fizzy mouthfeel, as enchanting plum,  chocolate and cedar flavors and touch of sweetness yield to a stiffening frame of hops.  This is a really unique beer that is a style of its own.  Purchased at De Bierkoning in Amsterdam and quaffed at home in Madison.

Look at that commercial, with the cartoon brewers in perfect harmony - - a cool assembly of super-hip cognoscenti, concocting the ultimate super brew.   WOW those cartoon people are cool, and brilliant - - so perfect, that their beer-creating moves are sublime choreography. This must be the best beer ever.    I actually havent had it.  I would never buy desolate glam swill like this - - another thin suggestion of actual flavor, in an over-hyped frame.   But I feel it is fair to rate it, since I already know what it tastes like - - it tastes like glamorized H2O with a smattering of more actual ingredients than their usual tasteless H20.   So, I think this is a valid rating, though actually the total score may be actually too high - - but I simply cant help myself for overrating it, since it is is obviously so frickin special.
Certainly the 2nd worst double IPA Ive had (after the one Trader Joes carries).  Dense, tight un-charming bitterness coupled with creepy fruity sweetness.  No redeeming characteristics.  Yuck.

This is a beer for special occasions.  The special occasion should be: if you are ready for gonzo, break-the-bank, beam-me-up-scotty, in-your-face, hoist-me-up-by-the-trousers, maniacal madness.   For me, that would be about seven times a day, but I can only handle ONE of these units.   Absolutely face-smacking, palate-whacking, Rome-sacking, brain-hijacking cracker jack.  Dense.  Like drinking an entire enchanted forest, with last years leaves, and all sundry tree bark shavings included (all of it put in a mash tun and brewed till properly condensed).
beer_name: Central Waters Kosmyk Charlies Y2K Catastrophe Ale

review_blob: If you are looking for something bright, zesty, potent, bursting with fun fruity flavor, but with just the right balance of bitterness, that dances with mysterious pleasures, and also knocks you on your can, you can start right here.   I LOVE this beer.

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob: More wee than heavy.  Wee carbonation.  Wee body.   Essentially, high octane root beer, but not as rich in flavor.   This might be good REALLY REALLY cold if you drink them fast, and if you drink four of them.
beer_name: Leinenkugels Big Eddy Wee Heavy Scotch Ale

review_blob: Was super thirsty, and although I had a backpack full of high-potency Belgos from Ambrosettis, wanted a cold beer on the train out of Berlin.  Could not have been more disappointed.  Watery, lawn-mower beer with a waft of bitter hops at the finish (not elegant hops like a recent draft Bitburger).  Even in a moment of dire thirst, it was hard to choke down - - a real chug-only with no redeeming charms.  Im sticking to Jever, KPi, and maybe Bit or Radeberger if I have to drink pils from now on.
Its like apricot cider, but kind of watery.   The carbonation gets you wanting more (carbonation).  The body gets you wanting more (body).  I generally like apricots though.

Got this in the closeout bin at Vaudree in Liege for 1e  (cant figure out why - -  the date punched is July 13).  Zesty, bright fizzy texture like well-fermented apple cider, and then the hops hit hard & deep, and then a sourness kicks in, with just the slightest hint of sweetness (sweetness is why I mostly avoid brunes, but this is more a hoppy sour beer).  Very lively on the palate - - it just dances all over the place.  This is a super tasty and really fun beer.  I wish I had bought the whole close-out binful (but I already  had over 40 bottles to haul back in my luggage to Germany).

I just finished my last bottle discovered at the back of the fridge and just had to doff my hat in praise.  The gentle hops in this one are set off so brilliantly by the sweetness/tartness of its blackness that it is incredibly balanced and supple.  I normally go for extreme beers, but this one is so extremely perfectly flavored, and the flavor dynamics are so multifaceted, that Im starting to cry in my beer.

This is an unusually  tight  "black"  beer compared to lusher, maltier BIPAs.   The hops kick in with a tree-bark bite, but then it gets interesting with a lasting sour bite at the back of the mouth.  This beer will kind of have you sitting bolt upright in your chair and your eyes may bulge a bit, but when you pay a premium for exotic numbers like this one, it is an essential aspect of the experience.
beer_name: Sand Creek Noir Black Belgian Barleywine

review_blob: Lush, bright, gently sweet, nicely hopped.  Barley wines can be tight, bitter tree bark vetches (though still wonderful), but this is expansive, fruity (apples, pears & sultanas), maple-bright celebration of everything autumn-rich but winter-sharp is a rare wonder.  I loved the New Glarus Iced Barley Wine and kept stocking up, only to imbibe it.   But this one is as pretty as it also is pleasing.  I figure I will be drawn back like a moth to a flame to buy it in bunches.  Makes me forget about last Sundays Packer game.   Almost.
beer_name: New Glarus Thumbprint Series Barley Wine

review_blob: Absoultely loved this from cask at the Draught House in Austin.  Presentation is like an English real ale, with the same free-drinking body.  But the sour twists and the beautifully accenting hops make this rare and wonderful - - an exciting play on a variety of understated themes - - sort of a farmhouse ESB saison barleywine.  I would give anything to have this stuff in the fridge, or otherwise handy, but I dont think they bottle it, and I live in Wisconsin.
beer_name: Jester King Boxers Revenge Barrel-Aged Wild Ale

review_blob: Interesting.  Has sort of an ethereal/zesty syrupyness.  Flavor is very much caramel candy - - somewhere between the lightness of Werthers Original and the gumminess of Kraft Caramels, followed by a steely alcohol attack and lingering bitterness.  Im finding this really hard to drink, and impossible to enjoy, but Im trying my best.
beer_name: Capital Square Bomber Series Eternal Flame

review_blob: This is a fantastic beer.  The roasty malts give a richness, but the hops have a piercing bite that turns it into fresh chocolate, anise, and pine.   The sensations in the mouth are incredible and change from moment to moment, and keep changing and shifting as the irresistible sips keep piling up minute to minute:  mild sweetness and richness gets upturned by a sourness, and then a piney hop bitterness starts a relentless campaign to invade and occupy every diverse dimension of the palate - - tongue, cheeks, even glottus - - various dimensions of the oral cavity all start clocking in like AP & UPI teletypes after some rare spectacle - - taste buds and oral nerves you never realized you had before flashing like Vegas neon, croaking like lit-up lily-pad frogs by nuclear plants, whole oral flavor networks swaying, and careening like decks of creaking plankwood on ancient war galleons.   You dont want this to end.    Thankfully, for physical constitution, I am only in the possession of this one bottle, and I cant remember where I got it.   But I will be Googling about it again real soon, and then buying a plane ticket to where I can get it again.
beer_name: Stone 15th Anniversary Escondidian Imperial Black IPA

review_blob: I kind of like the bit of sourness, and the dry, musty finish.  I wish it had more all-round flavor and zest though.  I really did enjoy it after periodically adding small handfuls of dried cranberries.

Very fizzy, very little head.  Light palate for a wee heavy  (wee heavy light?), and a club-soda-like finish just barely redeemed with faint flavors of molasses, birch bark, and carbon dioxide.  Can you tell Im not happy that I bought an entire 4-pack?  Hopefully the 10% will start kicking in quickly.
beer_name: Samuel Adams Imperial Series Wee Heavy

review_blob: This is one of those beers where it is very satisfying to drink the entire bomber in the course of an hour or so, since it is gentle, supple, and pleasing - - and by the time you finish it you will have experienced something delightful across different time & flavor-dimensional spaces (not to mention the inevitable changing states of intoxicating consciousness).  It is all prairie flowers & warm breezes, and it becomes more and more intriguing complex.
The aroma is lovely, but the flavor is tightly bitter, and it is kind of thin and flabby on the palate.  Lacks zest, sparkle, sweetness and fruit.  Well named.

I was surprised to see an Imperial Stout in this price range, so picked it up.  It makes sense now.  I guess Ive been spoiled by malt monsters, hop hammers, and alco-whores, but this one is thinner on the palate, dryer in the malt, and tamer in the hops.  Its not all that well-integrated either.   But I suppose you notice things like that when youre not slapped in the face by the flavor, mobbed on the palate by the texture, nor gob-smacked by a sumptuous finish.  Just not my style, I guess.  The other 5 bottles in the pack might be sitting in the fridge for a while, as other things clamor for attention.
beer_name: Central Waters Satin Solitude Imperial Stout

review_blob: This is, like, my new favorite beer ever.  I had it in Lexington, KY on draft a few weeks ago.  What blew me away, is that it was like the little hop cone that Oso brewing put in the Lupulus Maximus or whatever they call it.  The Lupulus Maximus or whatever is a fine big multo-IPA, but getting to chew on the cone that you have to force out of the bottle is the icing on the cake.  BUT, the ENTIRE pint of Founders Double Trouble is EQUAL to chewing on the little hop cone icing on the cake.   This is one amazing in-your-palate concentration of pine/citrus excellence.  Not as syrupy as Bells Hopslam - - just pure miniature pinecone on just the right lightish frame.  Ive tended to stay away from Founders products at the store because of their stupid cartoonish labels and namings, that look so gimmicky, but this is right smart stuff.

This is the future of beer.   At least for people like me who need things that grab you by the neck and wrestle you to the ground and make you cry uncle.   The future of beer includes a mass funeral for the generic "IPA"s that every brewery feels obliged to half-heartedly cook up so that guys in polo shirts or shirts with slogans on them might find adventurous, but are still cheap swill.   The future of beer includes this one, and thats why my fridge is filled with anything I can get my hands on that is massive in terms of malt, hops, yeast, fruit, alcohol - - and especially all-of-the-above.  Thats why my fridge will include this one, till it gets crowded out by things more apocalyptic.

Ive just finished the 4th in my four-pack over the last week or so, and for me it is one always worth having around.  Gorgeous gold/copper color, big rich aroma, deep autumn woods flavors with wet leaves and tree bark but also airy-sky brightness - - BIG hops, BIG malt.  No matter WHAT beer you have had before this, this one can put a happy cap on the evening.   Must stock multiple bottles of this in the deep recesses of the fridge.

The search for that rare but somehow always not-quite-right thing that is the promise of a magnificent weizenbock ends here.   Schneider Aventinus is archetypal, but has these off-elements.   The Paulaner version is assertive, but not all flowers and rainbows.  Ive had interesting domestic attempts, but they all ultimately skew off in awkward flavor directions.  This new Imperial Weizen from New Glarus is the bomb.  It is  florid, complex, soaring.  Incredible, incredible mouthfeel and richness.  Hops  perfectly balance the elaborate, potent, but still fine fruitiness.  This is an incredible beer.   It leaves the rest of weizendom and even weizenbockdom in the dust - - so fresh, lush, and alive - -and it even puts the entire sordid aggregation of Belgian TRIPELdom to shame.  This is, like, what tripels SHOULD be.  Even the Piraats will be doffing their caps as they bow.   Boffo.
beer_name: New Glarus Thumbprint Series Imperial Weizen

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob: What makes this so much fun is how pricklingly zesty it is for a big, dense, multi-layered (flavors changesecond to second - - here a fruit, there a malt, then some roast, then some black liquorice, and then back to fruit again).  Its not a murky mass - -its a fun beer.
beer_name: Leinenkugels Big Eddy Russian Imperial Stout
